questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is truly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Decreased risk of colon cancer

Explanation:

The true association of hormone replacement therapy is with a decreased risk of colon cancer.

Hormone replacement therapy

  • This is used for the treatment of menopausal symptoms
  • They are usually estrogen and occasionally in combination with progesterone
  • HRT decreases the risk of colon cancer due to the protective effects of estrogen
  • Hence, the incidence of colon cancer is rare amongst women of reproductive age group compared to men of the same age group

Indications of HRT:

  • Therapeutic:
    • Symptomatic menopausal women
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic:
  • Patients at high risk for menopausal complications like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, stroke, colon cancer, etc
  • Premature menopause: Spontaneous following surgery or cancer therapy

 

Breast cancer risk (Option A) is increased by hyperestrogenism. Breast cancer following HRT is usually low-grade and shows a good prognosis.

Estrogen replacement (Option B) can increase the risk of well-differentiated endometrial carcinoma. The addition of progesterone to estrogen reduces the risk of endometrial cancer.

After menopause, bone density decreases every year, leading to osteopenia and, eventually, osteoporosis (Option C). Osteoporosis would usually result in fractures of vertebrae, femur and wrist. HRT using estrogen protects against osteoporosis and decreases the risk of fractures.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following will you do to evaluate the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation: Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate patients with post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Indications for Endometrial Biopsy:

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Atypical glandular or endometrial cells on cervical cytology
  • Cancer screening (e.g., hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer)
  • Follow-up and surveillance of previously diagnosed endometrial hyperplasia
  • Postmenopausal bleeding

 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) is the first-line investigation for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding. Since TVS is not among the available options, endometrial sampling becomes the best choice in this case.

 

Pap smear (Option A): Primarily used for cervical cancer screening in women over 21 who have been sexually active for at least three years. It does not assess the endometrium, making it unsuitable for postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Visual inspection with iodine (Option B), also called Schiller’s test, detects cervical abnormalities in facilities lacking Pap smear access. It evaluates the cervix and vagina as in cases of carcinoma cervix, not the endometrium, and is inappropriate for postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Colposcopy (Option C) examines the cervix, vagina, and vulva. It is challenging in postmenopausal women due to a narrowed vagina, senile vaginitis, poorly visible squamocolumnar junction, and atrophied cervix.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of hypertension presents with vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure her that this is normal at her age
Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound
Refer her to cardiology before any further evaluation
Start antihypertensives and observe for 1 week

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation: Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step, because, postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is never normal and should be treated as endometrial carcinoma until proven otherwise.

  • Hypertension is a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma, but it does not delay the need for prompt evaluation.
  • The initial work-up includes pelvic examination, Pap smear (for cervical pathology), and transvaginal ultrasound to assess endometrial thickness; an endometrial biopsy is indicated if thickness >4 mm or ultrasound is suspicious.

Reassure her that this is normal at her age (Option A): PMB is always pathological until proven otherwise. So, reassurance without evaluation risks missing malignancy.

Refer her to cardiology before any further evaluation (Option C): While hypertension should be addressed, it does not delay urgent gynecologic evaluation for PMB.

Start antihypertensives and observe for 1 week (Option D): Observation is inappropriate in PMB. Diagnostic work-up should be immediate.
